>A lot of Garga's defensive profile comes from the fact that it can't get status'd PERIOD and has a Ghost resist.
Garganacl can be taunted, Good as Gold blocks Taunt. Paralysis, Toxic, and Burn can be answered by tera, or Rest, Rest/Curse/Iron Defense which can't be taunted if you have Good as Gold.
Gholdego meanwhile, is already immune to toxic, doesn't care about burn and MIGHT not care about paralysis depending on the set. What it gets sent in to spinblock, usually Ground type or Electric defog users, can beat it once it switches in.
The Ghost resist, while good and thematic, doesn't really impact its matchups at all since pure Rock has a lot of weakneses and Ghost isn't one of them. But for Gholdengo it's a huge game changer as that narrows what can beat it

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53213867
Dynamax isn't even in natdex AG. The entire reason why it became unplayable was because of Assist and Revival Blessing. At the top of the ladder, prankster assist into revival blessing meant you could just keep reviving your mons over and over, and you essentially had to have a dedicated counter just for this specific strategy. People kept asking for revive to be banned, but they can't ban anything in AG, so they just deleted the ladder instead.

Of course, this entire thing is fucking stupid because Assist shouldn't be able to call Revival Blessing in the first place, because it's a blatantly broken strategy. They argued that since Gamefreak didn't program an exception for Assist to call Revival Blessing, it was a-okay. The issue there being that Assist hasn't existed since Gen 8 and Gamefreak wouldn't program an exception for a move that doesn't exist, and Assist is programmed to call moves by default unless a move is explicitly in its blacklist.

Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?

A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

Obscure Unown Fact!
Due to the way shinies work in generation 2, all shinies can only have hidden power grass or dragon.
Unown's formes are based on their IV values, as well. A shiny Unown can only have one of the aforementioned hidden powers and it can only be either Unown "I" or Unown "V", funnily enough.

posts.com:
Obscure Unown Fact!
The shininess wonkiness of Unown does not end in gen 2. Generation 3 brings us Unown on tanoby ruins, in Fire Red and Leaf Green. They do not follow the standard rate of Pokémon, and certain formes are more common than others when it comes to shininess, due to the PID of each pokémon programmed into the game.
Unown "!", in particular (a 1% encounter in an out of itself).
Unown A, B, C and D have a 1/5x120 shiny rate at minimum, for example. Meanwhile Unown ! (A 1% ENCOUNTER, MIND YOU) has a rate of approximately 1/9216 with certain values. And Unowns I, J, K, L, U, V, W, X can have a rate as low as 1/18,432

In gen 1 they could be paralysed by body slam and thunder wave, but not by damage-dealing electric moves. This is because gen 1 was coded so moves that can inflict status as a secondary effect never do so against a target of the same type as the move. For most part that makes sense: flamethrower won't burn a fire type, poison sting won't poison a poison type, etc. But it does have the odd side-effect of making normal types unable to be paralyzed by body slam.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53201653
In Gen I and II, the defeated Pokémon's base stats are given as EVs. That's why people call it stat experience for those games, because you're no longer gaining 1-3 points per battle where a stat caps at 255 (252 Gen VI+).

If you defeat a Pidgey, you get
>HP: 40
>Attack: 45
>Defense: 40
>Speed: 56
>Special: 35
And stat experience caps at 65535 per stat. The way the math works, it's the same as having 63 additional points by level 100 like EVs, the math is just more unwieldy. The other difference is that there's no collective 510 cap (or equivalent 131,070), you can raise every stat by its maximum 63 points.

Where things get a bit more complex is IVs (or DVs which is how people differentiate them from IVs). IVs are 0-31 and serve as that many extra points at level 100. DVs are 0-15, and that value multiplied by 2 is the extra points, so it's actually +2, +4, +6... ...+30 max. DVs are generated for Attack, Defense, Special, and Speed (this is the order by the way), and the HP DV is the first bit of each. So if your DVs for those four stats are all 8 (1000) or higher, your HP is a guaranteed 15 (1111).
0000 = 0, 1000 = 8
0001 = 1, 1001 = 9
0010 = 2, 1010 = 10
0011 = 3, 1011 = 11
0100 = 4, 1100 = 12
0101 = 5, 1101 = 13
0110 = 6, 1110 = 14
0111 = 7, 1111 = 15
Now the problem is that the RNG in the game isn't perfect and doesn't generate every combination (65,536) of DVs. It does for Pokémon of certain encounter types and area encounter frequencies, but perfect DVs aren't possible for a number of Pokémon because of the areas they're found in. Mind you with breeding in Gen II, this should mostly be fixable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53201867
You're right that it takes a level up for it to calculate new stat experience, but you can also do it by depositing the Pokémon, switching boxes, and switching back. The game doesn't keep the stats of Pokémon in other boxes memorized like it does for your current box and party, only their levels, DVs, and stat experience, so it just recalculates your stats when you switch a box to your current box. It does this to save space, and doing so will apply accrued stat experience.

>>53201875
https://www.smogon.com/forums/threads/15-15-15-15-dvs-are-impossible-in-most-cases.3573219/
This thread goes into more detail.

To put the stat experience thing into more perspective, let's say you're playing an emulator and you've hacked Pidgey and Rattata's base stats to 255 in every stat so you can just grind Route 1. It would take you 257 battles to max all your stats.

>>53202096
Well in Gen I, all Trainer Pokémon have 0 stat experience themselves, while their DVs are are the same across the board.
Also I was wrong, it's the last bit that's taken to calculate the HP DV, not the first, so if every DV is an odd number (ends in a 1), the HP DV will be perfect. In Gen I, all Trainer DVs are 1001/1000/1000/1000 (9/8/8/8 for Atk/Def/Spd/Spe), making HP 1000 (8). All Trainer movesets use the Pokémon's most recently learned 4 moves, which is why Pokémon that evolve from stones are pretty gimped when used by NPCs and is why your rival's Exeggutor only has 3 moves.

In Gen II, DVs are determined by Trainer class (specifically Trainer sprite, so both rival sprites count as different classes, each Gym Leader, each Elite Four, etc.), and it's like that from that game onward. Red is 15/13/13/14 (1110 = 14 HP). I assume Stadium has more thought put into it, because apparently the Battle Tower in Crystal gives every Trainer custom DVs and stat experience.

posts.com: IIRC in gen 4 the way the Cute Charm ability's secondary effect (increase the chance to encounter pokemon of the opposite gender to 66,6 % if the pokemon with the ability was in your 1st slot) worked was that if the ability activated the game would not randomize the wild pokemon's stats as normal, and instead randomly determine the pokemon's nature and then assign it IVs based on a template (one for each nature) generated based on your hidden trainer ID generated when you start a new game. Because shinies were also determined by IVs it was possible have a hidden ID that causes pokemon of one nature spawned through Cute Charm to always be shiny, massively increasing the odds of finding a shiny (66,6 % chance the ability triggers when you encounter a wild pokemons and 4 % chance it has the right nature, which is still far better than the 0,025 % chance you normally have of finding a shiny). Of course, the odds of getting the right hidden ID by chance is atronomically low, but people did figure how to manipulate the RNG to ensure you get it.

>>53202359
I was starting to think that maybe they meant something like that, like every name is in an array.

If we're talking obscure facts, I pull this one out like maybe once a year. I went through all the Trainer names in Japanese GS. People usually know this, but there are Trainers whose names are references to people, like Trainers who are named Ikue from game to game using Pikachu. This started in Gen II, and it extends to practically every character in the game in Japanese, rarely is a name just a name. From characters like Schoolboy Manabu (学ぶ is the verb to learn) and Bird Keeper Tsubasa (翼 means wing) to Poké Fan Megumi named after Megumi Hayashibara and practically every staff member on the credits being referenced as a character somewhere in the game. There are even some really obscure ones, like Atsuko (after Atsuko Nishida) only appearing as a wrong name when you get misdialed by Picnicker Liz, same with Tsunekazu (Tsunekazu Ishihara) with someone from the lighthouse. It's impossible to tell practically any of references outside of the Japanese games. But what's even crazier is that 4Kids actually used Nintendo's localized English names if the corresponding Japanese name appeared in the Johto anime. In The Legend of Thunder, there's Jimmy (Kenta) and Vincent (Jun'ichi), whose names 4Kids decided on because of the NPCs Youngster Kenta (Jimmy) and Guitarist Jun'ichi (Vincent), who also happened to be Gen II's Masuda reference (Guitarist Masuda in Crystal's Battle Tower isn't in the Japanese game because of how the Battle Tower was altered). You can find more examples in random filler episodes of the Johto anime.

In the Gen III games, even though a number of names were reused, they were given different translated names. And because Gen I NPCs were getting names in FRLG, a lot of those Hoenn names carry over to them. Eventually the localization ended up having to integrate the older Gen II names to maintain consistency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
BW > BW2
BW2 isn’t bad, but it seems like a clear attempt to pander to the people who hated BW (via adding national dex mons right from the beginning, adding more tutorials, a battle frontier-life, etc) and 80% of it is still BW with no change outside of a few encounter spots, Route 4, and some minor endgame stuff. I would’ve preferred at least a bit more overhauling of Unova; as is, after I get to Castelia the game feels extremely stale to me all the way until Reversal Mountain.
I also find that the music is generally worse, and I really dislike almost all of the character designs. The protagonists look insanely retarded, and your rival (alongside Marlon) looks equally-as dumb. Bianca’s glasses don’t fit her and her wardrobe seems to clash with itself.
Story is also worse, with Hugh never shutting up about the Purrloin to the point of being one-note, and having Plasma as some dumb terrorists again kills any impact they could’ve had when their goal was actually interesting in the originals.
The games also hold your hand a significant amount more in BW2 than in the original, to the point where you’re still getting tutorials after the second fucking gym leader, and they started a lot of trends that make modern games such a slog (excessive handholding and tutorials, bloated regional dexes, dual third versions instead of just one, etc)
BW2 may be better in many traditional aspects (more longevity through side activities like the PWT and Pokestar Studios, more variety in wild encounters, arguably a better difficulty curve) but I prefer BW since it just seems much tighter and definitely a lot more ambitious. BW2 just feels like a defeated resignation to the rabid fans who were screeching about charizard and pikachu being missing from the originals.

I wish we got more sequels, and saw how the world changed after our adventures, than another remake. After BDSP I can only imagine how bad BW will be. Maybe we will be lucky and they will conclude that it isn't popular enough and do another Kanto again.

I used to relish the remakes. Now I just pray my favourite games remain mostly unmolested.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53212128
An idea and a suggestion of a concept is better than nothing at all.

Team Galactic felt so empty in DP. At that point in the franchise, it felt like they were there being an evil team and doing evil deeds for its own sake. Because a Pokémon game needs an evil team. That's the formula. In Platinum they tried to flesh out Cyrus and Galactic a little more, but I don't understand most of what the rank and file grunts were doing or what they personally gained from it.

Team Rocket didn't need lofty goals or justification because they were a criminal gang. That was it. The crime and personal gain was the point.

RSE tried to give Aqua/Magma something slightly more nuanced, being some breed of environmental activists turned extremists. It was dumb, excessive and nonsensical, but I at least understand the core idea. I think this was also the point where "evil team wants world domination" was truly cemented in the franchise.

Team Plasma were such a breath of fresh air. Their objective as it is presented at first has moral ambiguity and the morality of the franchise's core mechanic has been questioned for years outside the game. The fact that GF would even dare to entertain the idea was bold for a franchise founded on YOU GOOD, ENEMY TEAM BAD ironically black and white morality.

Of course, it was secretly that very morality at the core of Plasma in the end. N as the puppet leader was true to his convictions, but even he is forced to go through the whole I WRONG, PROTAGONIST RIGHT revelation.

So it was a step in the right direction. A step is better than standing still. And BW2 did explore the other side of these ideas much better.

Such a shame that the very next game reverted to French Ganondorf's nonsensical plan to destroy the world. There were brief shades of a deeper idea with his hatred of people taking advantage of good intentions, but again the grunts don't reflect this idea.

"Oh, you are not as fashionable as me? Guess you deserve to die!"

>>53213490
Who said that gen 5 executed its ideas flawlessly? The games have plenty of issues I could criticise. I did criticise them in my post, and lamented that it didn't execute on them properly.

I disagree with your contention that the previous games executed on their ideas successfully. They sold well, admittedly declining since gen 1. (Indeed the franchise has only started to reach gen 1 levels of sales on the Switch.) But selling well on one formula does not mean that that formula is a good one, that it cannot be improved or that it should be followed in the future.

As I said, gen 1 (and 2 since it was virtually a sequel to 1 in the way GF were handling the franchise at that point. It was expected to be the last game.) could get by with its more primitive story given the limits of the platform, the fact that it was the first one and there was no established formula and Team Rocket's ambitions did not go beyond crime for profit. Giovanni hinted at world domination, but that may have been blustering or hyperbole on his part. We only had a few lines on dialogue to go off and the actions of the team as a whole rarely went beyond petty crime, verging on terrorism at times.

RSE tried to give the teams a grander, ethical and planetspanning goal, but I already spoke on the flaws with that.

Gen 4 arrived when the franchise was in something of a slump. Not selling poorly, usually topping charts and selling in the millions. But compared to previous heights, a low point. DPPt followed the same formula and morality as previous games. Team bad, you good, get gym badges, defeat team, become champion, credits. Nowhere did it suggest that Galactic were in the right or there might be moral questions. And again, what did the grunts get out of Cyrus' plan that he quickly told you at the end of the game? Did they even know it?

I feel Team Flare are Team Galactic again. Did most grunts even know the plan? They talk about fashion in most encounters.

>>53213881
You have missed my point.

Or rather, you have focused too much on my liking of the moral ambiguity of Black and White's themes and have perhaps inferred that I think it is the only measure of a story's depth or maturity.

There are plenty of deep, insightful stories with little to no moral ambiguity. Equally there are stories that aspire to say something profound but despite all their allusions to something deeper, come across as shallow, desperate, immature or simply directionless. (Sadly I fear BW may sometimes lean too much towards the latter, but at least I believe there is an earnest attempt that loses confidence in itself by the end.)

If Cyrus had succeeded in his plan, what would that achieve? What would it mean? What was the overarching theme of Galactic's role in the story, besides being an antagonistic force?

I know N believed Plasma's success would have lead to a happier world for Pokémon he believed to be abused (even if the true nature of Plasma did not actually seek anything of the sort).

It's fair enough to think that and we all have our own interpretation on these things. If all the games speak to you, that's great.

There always has to be a worst game, though. One that fell short. Just as one rose to become the best of a series in our eyes. Something that resonates strongly with you will fall flat for others. I think we can learn a lot about these games and their impact upon us through critique and discussing these criticisms with others, the games we don't like as much as the ones we love.

DP were one of the weaker installments in my eyes. (Not the worst. I quite like them in spite of my complaints.) In addition to the slow gameplay and criticisms of the region design, the plot is one of the weaker elements. It improved somewhat in Platinum, but I still don't think it gave me enough for Galactic to make sense.

I don't understand why anyone followed Cyrus. Perhaps it made sense for him to become god of a new world or whatever, but why would anyone else go along with his plan? Nihilism? Where is the suffering in the world Cyrus seeks to eliminate? Who is suffering beyond thise harmed by Galactic themselves?

Where does the game show us this?

posts.com:
I personally believe ALL ships are unlikely but I think these last 20 threads as well as Serebii and twitter have given me a comprehensive picture of the shippersphere

There's two simple issues that keep it in a perpetual state of conflict

>Ash and Misty was teased first
>Ash and Serena was teased harder

And the expectations range between:

>Ash will timeskip into an adult already married to misty/serena
>Ash will have a sendoff implying that he will later become romantically involved with misty/serena
>Ash will not have any romance of any sort
>Misty will overcome her sheepishness from the second MPM episode and initiate a relationship with Ash
>"Milfty" was a cameo appearance of Misty's future self akin to part 2 characters having joke cameos in Naruto

Expectedly the least common serious suggestion is that Ash will confess to anyone. Or if he does it will be indirect or quirky.
Optimistic Misty fans seem to vastly outnumber optimistic Serena fans. Either that or the Serena fans are quieter
Non shippers and Amourfans alike seem to prefer an ambiguous ending, as Pokemon is not a romantic show(non shippers) and an ambiguous ending would leave Serena with the most explicit conclusion (amour fans).

Various comparisons to the Naruto franchise specifically. Though arguably not the best comparison beyond the personalities of the characters in question. We've seen directly into Sakura's brain to know she doesn't like Naruto back. Regardless, this is the most popular comparison
Ironically the last 11 Episodes of Naruto were about shipping. The last episode was a wedding and Naruto took a backseat to Iruka and Hinata in the protagonist role.

My only perspective here are that Naruto is the closest to Pokemon in terms of length and character so people jump that comparison.

I have had more shipping concepts hammered into my head in the last month than in all my 29 years

Quick capture like one finger on the bottom left berries and other throwing the ball? Its supposed to, but I couldn't figure out how to do it.
I tried all the tricks like switching DNS servers and the like, but no dice.

MelonDS doesn't seem to always play too well with Pokemon hacks.
Maybe I'm just tech illiterate (I've been called worse) but getting things to work sometimes is a pain.
Like I could only get Blazed Black to load on an older version of MelonDS. And VW2R simply won't be recognized if the emulator is in DSi mode but normal Volt White will. I guess the program verification the console does doesn't like the code changes.
Can't complain too much given all the work thats been put into the emulator, but limitations pop up once in a while.

>>53183007
Quite a lot.
Its significantly different to the original BlazedBlack2. Beyond just adding Fairy types, evolutions have been redone, stat trainers have been added, teams for gym leaders and bosses have been redone, certain events have been changed and short cuts like Clay Tunnel are opened up early giving you greater access to monsters in the mid game.
Its certainly not a different hack entirely or anything. But it is an improvement on what was already pretty solid.

Here's my take on types:

Bug-type
- Bug no longer resists Fighting.
- Bug now resists Psychic.

Electric-type
- Electric is now weak to Ghost.

Fairy-type
- Fairy no longer resists Bug.
- Fairy is now weak to Grass and Psychic.

Fighting
- Fighting no longer resists Bug.

Ghost-type
- Ghost no longer resists Bug.
- Ghost now resists Electric.

Grass-type
- Grass is now immune to Fairy.

Ground-type
- Ground is no longer weak to Water.
- Ground is now weak to Steel.

Ice-type
- Ice now resists Ground and Flying

Psychic-type
- Psychic now resists Fairy.

Water-type
- Water is now weak to Poison.

Rock-type
- Rock is no longer weak to Grass.

Steel-type
- Steel is now weak to Electric.
- Steel is no longer immune to Poison, it just resists it, but it remains immune to Poison status.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53213910
>>53213929
The Pokemon id is internally a 16-bit number so you could have 65535 Pokemon, but you would run out of ROM space with sprites and cries way before that. Same with moves. Abilities are limited to 256.

Since you have the source code for the game, you could change the data types used to increase the limits, making ROM space the only hard limit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53214167
You're the zoomer if you think the sprotes used to be based on the sugimori artworks at any point. In the first gen, specifically with red and green the sprites came first and sugimori's artwork was just his interpretation of the sprites, which is why there is such a discrepancy between the sprites and artwork. In gens 2 and 3 they worked on the sprites and changed them multiple times until they were satisfied, at which point sugi would "finalize" the designs in his artworks. That is why you see beta sprites that are starkly different from what made it into the game. In gen 4 they were slowly shifting away from aprites being the primary design medium and from gen 5 onward the sprites and models were based on concept art with the official sugi art always coming at the end. In gen 7 they only change to how they operated was that other artists started making official pokemon art

I can't help but feel something is artificial about them. The illusion of them being natural to their habitat just doesn't jive with me, especially when you look at their latter form. It's probably just me, but when comparing scorbunny to something like mudkip, I can't help but feel something is off when compared to the former. They both have the same beady black eyes to them, a roughly analogous head to body proportion, with the only difference between them being typing, color, and the number of legs that they stand on.

Hell, even their limbs are blobby as well. But no matter how long I look at scorbunny and the likes of sobble, it feels like something is off no matter what.

It's annoying, not being able to pin down the precise factors that just rub me off the wrong way about the newer starters. Even knowing that they were purpose made to be mascots, something still feels off about them even when compared to other purpose built mascots from the past.

Is it the proportions? The shape? The concept? I can only guess.

Oh well, have a cute chikorita.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53213601
>For SwSh
game is so shit that modding isn't enough to fix it. You'd need to completely revamp the level-design AND the pacing of the game in order for it to be bearable.
dexcut is also physically impossible to remedy in non-BDSP, post-B2W2 games since we can't add mons, only replace them.
>For PLA
I think that straight-up, there's a lack of interest for this one? The biggest thing PLA lacks is a postgame area, but obviously we can't fucking add maps in non-BDSP games.
PLA doesn't really need much fixes aside from a non-shit battle system, which is a thing we also can't change.
>For SV
Unless this has changed since I last checked, we STILL don't have a Trainer editor. so lol.
pnly a few mods exist as a result, and it's mostly to fix SV's most retarded decisions, like PLAmons being unavailable, Finizen's evo method, garbage shinies, etc
We -are- experimenting on scaling, but it's not quite functional in a convenient way yet.
>For BDSP
That is just untrue. BDSP modding is fucking cracked and already outpacing DS-era modding
in BDSP you can:
- add any mon, not limited in moveset slots either
- freely change encounter tables
- add new animations and moves
- change some of the battle engine mechanics (ex Hail to Snow, Freeze to Frostbite)
and we are experimenting with adding custom maps. The one thing that may never be done is adding Battle Frontier, but I wouldn't speak too fast
If we don't see a lot of romhacks at the moment, it's because Luminescent has the monopoly until it releases.

It's a mix of artists sticking with the starter "traditions" and sicking with what's popular. Plus there's always the case of artists looking around at art for inspiration, and using that to fuel their own work. Either intentionally or unintentionally.
Unintentionally meaning they came across a decent minotaur or something a long while back, and when coming up with their own Fire minotaur ideas, pulled from that idea that came across without realizing it.
Pretty much the reason why GameFreak or whoever aren't allowed to look at fakemon online.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53204636
>>53204668
adding skeletal bits is actually really bad advice and the main reason a lot of fakemon look like fakemon
the only skeletal pokemon we've ever truly had has been Houndstone, and even that's only partially skeleton
most ghost types tend to stick to wispy forms and/or lots of wispy bits, as well as a lot of dark purples/blacks/reds

there's some weird exceptions to the rule like Decidueye and Litwick that hardly look ghostly at all, but in general it's better to stick to:
>darker/more washed-out colors, especially purple/black/yellow for whatever reason (Giratina, Palossand, Shedinja, Cofagrigus- it's weirdly common?)
>either very wispy bodies (Marshadow, Misdreavus, Gastly, Spiritomb) or a very clearly possessed object (Phantump, Chandelure, Banette, Cofagrigus again)
>sunken eyes and/or colored scleras. Also just weird eye shapes in general (Gourgeist, Rotom, Drifblim, Lunala, Dhelmise)

these are all the essential elements to creating a good ghost type, and anything further is either overkill or acceptable as a singular gimmick
newer gens have obviously blurred the rules on this because the longer this franchise goes on the less established conventions it keeps in place in regards to monster design, but Ghosts have been some of the most consistent and consistently good designs in the series and I think this is why

So I have a simple theory on the lookalikes, they are fans who dress like people they look up to. In this case said people to look up to would be Ash, Misty, and Brock. I think the "Milftsty" one is the most evident of this as her outfit is similar but more modest than Misty's (full length pants, t-shirt that covers the middriff). The two Ash lookalikes are interesting in that they are both black haired, the older one has Ash's shirt, while the younger one has a red and white cap with no logo. The Brock one I will say looks like a mini brock, the only difference is an emphasis on yellow with an accent of green instead of the vice versa.
>However I wouldn't say this is simply just fans and nothing more. As the writers and animators like to sneak in things that can have multiple meanings. For all we can merely speculate at the moment without more sufficient evidence from later episode, there might be a deeper meaning there might not be.

This episode also provided an interesting insight into how our trio view team rocket in their disguises. They give them the benefit of the doubt because they have encountered enough Jennys and Joys where people who look like others just exist. As there is always a slim chance that one day they could encounter those who look like Jesse & James but are not them.

I think its always been a flimsy excuse, as far back as episode 3 of the OS.

Misty was trying to come up with a reason back then, when asked by Ash, why she is following him. She starts off nervous and you can hear her words in japanese and english both have a wavering tone to them.
>"M-my bike. I'm holding you responsible for my bike."
And then when Ash doesn't take her seriously she gets angry and focuses more on the bike in her language. Repeating the word "bike".

These are telltale signs of lying.

However if you don't believe me. Then episode 2 of the OS shows much more about how much the bike meant to her. In english she is much more angry with Ash about the matter and gives him a verbal lashing. But in japanese she is more mildly annoyed and compares her ruined bike to fried fish.

The greatest wool pulled over many peoples eyes is the one done by 4kids in regards to that bike, not the romance. The bike joke persisted longer than what was intended for in the japanese version.

As even in later episodes, like The Misty Mermaid (ep61), at the end of the episode there is different dialogue in Ash and Misty's conversation as they are walking away from Cerulean City.

>Satoshi: "Hanada Gym isn't really a Pokemon Gym is it?"
>Kasumi: "Try not to think too much about it."

>Ash: "Misty, you did really great back there."
>Misty: "Save the sweet talk Ash. You still owe me a bike."

>>53212129
The most interesting thing about Misty's sun and moon outfit is the flowers in her hair. Those are hibiscus flowers, they are very iconic flowers to places like Hawaii or in this Alola. She has at least two yellow flowers and one red flower. To borrow from Brockschizo for a moment with flower meaning:
>Yellow Hibiscus flowers mean happiness, sunshine, and good luck.
>Red Hibiscus flowers mean passion and deep romantic love.
Hibiscus flowers are considered very feminine, are often given to girls.
>According to Polynesians and Hawaiians, depending on what side they of the head they are worn, this can also be a sign if a girl is single or not. With Misty's flowers, if you are standing in front of her , it means she is single and available. If you are standing with her, she is attached, aka already taken.
>In Japan the flowers also have a meaning of gentleness and hospitality.
>In Malyasia the flowers also are known as celebration flowers.
>In China they take on also a meaning of the afterlife and of immortality.
>In Egypt, the flowers were associated with romantic fervor and lust. They believed you could make the petals of a hibiscus flower into a tea and it would act as an aphrodisiac. Turning a hibiscus flower into a tea is still a popular thing to do as it has a tart flavor like cranberries and it helps with a variety of things to help the body be healthy.
>In Victorian England, the flower gained a meaning of "delicate beauty".

There are people who take shipping as this generally cute and funny innocuous thing and then there are people who see other shippings as an existential threat to them.
Think of how sport fans get about their favorite team. They all but forget about the entertainment side and focus more on competing. Competing with the opposition, competing with the oppositions fans. They have to win, Lizard brain says must beat opponents. Opponents must be hurt.

Then there's the third camp that's on the sidelines that may or may not ship but finds the conflict tiresome.
There's people who have identified with a Ship that is "dying" and are personally hurt or threatened by another one "gaining momentum" while conversely there are people galvanized by a rising ship and excitedly gloating

Any Pokemon ripoff like TemTem or Nexomon is dead in the water because it’s just trying to be the Pepsi to Pokemon’s Coca-Cola. The two other wildly successful series in the genre are Digimon and Monster Hunter, both of which take bold steps towards their own identity, the most important of which being their OWN design philosophy, and so I’ve modeled my concept after the deviations those series took. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53207069
The Pokemon Killer is an inherently untenable genre.

Yokai, Monster Rancher, TemTem... it's a fucking graveyard.

For all of Pokemon's flaws, it's one of the most versatile monster games out there. Want a single player campaign? It has that. Want to do multi player competitive with a fully fledge metagame? Done. Want to autistically hunt for Pokemon with slightly swapped color palettes? Check. All wrapped in a game with collectathon and social aspects.

The only game afaik that really tried to tackle that was TemTem and they were stupid enough to make it an MMO. Most of these games' monster designs or atrociously soulless or overly "monstrous". Other games like Monster Hunter are somewhat successful, but they only really excel at the single player aspect.

Pokemon's core design problem probably is that it's too many things to too many people, but that's also ironically its appeal. It's inherently hard to do all the things a core Pokemon game does. Not even Pokemon does them well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209991
Left is a type wheel, right is a type chart. Type wheels allow for more definitive type distribution, easier matchups (type charts are HARD to teach players if you’re not just 1:1 ripping off pokemon’s types and effectivenesses), and a combat system that overall allows for individual monster abilities to push the bounds of combat. When every monster is 1 of 6 monotypes with all attacks taking on their type, you can go crazy on their signature abilities. Monster Catcher RPGs tend to die by their assumption that they can do what Pokemon does, but they can’t. A system that prioritizes a smaller number of monotypes allows for easily accessible combat and a design emphasis on making every monster have a unique play style.

>>53205695
>>Instead of the usual amnesia human-turned-to-pokemon, what would you do to change up the formula?

In terms of the mechanics, make the self-insert protagonist a bit like the Elder scrolls protagonist. Meaning, you pick your starter, and then the story begins by you arriving in a new town by ship (or Lapras, I don't care) or something like that. You get some dialogue options regarding your background, but other than that, the game never mentions your past and never makes a big deal about it.
Make the partner an interesting charcter with a deep backstory to compensate.


Also, make the games more relaxed. Let me do the main story at my own pace, give me plenty of optional side missions, give me a more diverse range of jobs.

In terms of story, make the game take place where the humans have been extinct for a couple hundered years or so. The dungeons are mostly set in the leftovers of human society, like overgrown cities, skyscrapers and so on. Imagine exploring the rusty remains of a giant cruise ship.
Only a few select Pokemon with extremly long livespans have been around the time humans existed, the rest views the humans like Skyrim views the Dwemer.
The narrative would then revolve around researching the remains of human society and find out what brought its doom.

/vpwt/ - Reality vs Expectation edition
>post fanfics you like
>share your own fics, ask for advice, post story updates
>discuss writerly struggles with fellow writefriends

Previous Thread: >>53154813

Check out the catalog for a directory of fics from fellow writefags: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1PtN4D_9CSw8JJ9uO6v0oQqdtKEkS8aFAvfxqI96XfSE
Gallery of art drawn for stories in the thread: https://imgur.com/a/sjdck

>Can I post NSFW fics?
There are no rules against NSFW text links.

>How should I post my fics?
If it's short enough to fit into a couple of posts, posting to the thread is fine. If you want to share longer works, or if you want more permanent storage, you can link to a host: fanfiction.net, AO3, Pastebin, or Google Docs.

>I'm not a writer but I want to contribute
Feel free to give stories posted a read and critique as you see fit. Keep it relevent to the story.
>Can I request something?
You're encouraged to post prompts, i.e. short snippets or greentext sequences describing your ideas. You can also expand on prompts posted by others. If writing an entire story from start to finish feels too daunting, this is a way to get started.

>I have this idea about [event/technology/...]
Feel free to post your thoughts about how specific parts of the Pokémon world function as well. Worldbuilding is always welcome.

>Can I add a fic I wrote to the catalog?
Check the catalog for the submission link. Fill out the form with all the necessary information and it will be submitted for review automatically.

We're also looking to collect ideas for fanfics as a resource for stumped writers. Feel free to throw an idea out there; someone may choose to use it themselves!
Ideabin: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1X072SSWulcC6RJRrPA6v9XtyohRybvMBl6Fh49wHsRw

>>53213438
I haven't played PMD since I was a teenager, I'm pretty sure, but there's simply more effort put into the narrative than in the mainline games. The player character being turned into a Pokemon presents a mystery that revolves around them, and IIRC, they actually have thoughts and stuff you can see and read. In the mainline games, things are a bit more nebulous with the Protagonist. Sure the player themselves is expected to beat the League because they have to in order for the game to be over, and the player CHARACTER has been asked to complete the Pokedex/stop an evil organization, but it always feels like the story is happening around that character and not like it is about them, wherein Mystery Dungeon, this is simply not true. At least in Explorers of Time/Darkness. The player character has a complex history, relationships that feel substantial, and a goal they were chasing prior to the beginning of the story. Mystery Dungeon also has twists, and more fleshed out characters; in fact everyone's personalities shine a little better because they're not just sprites, they have portraits and stuff.

If you think Mystery Dungeon isn't that impressive, that's fine, but that just means the mainline games (which I prefer because I don't like playing as a talking Pokemon that much) are even less impressive.

>>53206848
Noland has Pinsir because they needed more Bug-types at the launch of the game and as the Frontier Brain of the Battle Factory, you can give him whatever. The only other Bug-type pair when the game launched was Bugsy & Beedrill. It's the same reason Thorton was in at launch and was paired with Bronzong. It seems to match him better than Pinsir does Noland, but it was chosen because the only other Steel-type pair was Wikstrom & Aegislash.

During Anniversary 2021, there were three Master Fair characters, these are the characters they want you to drop gems on. Lillie & Lunala (it's not Nebby, she says she received it as a Cosmog from the Gen VII MC), N & Reshiram (he already had Zekrom, and he just vaguely alludes that he met and befriended Reshiram after traveling with Zekrom following the ending of BW), and Steven & Rayquaza. The last one is pure fanservice since Zinnia already pairs up with Rayquaza in the game, but his is shiny and can Mega Evolve (unfortunately it's pretty shit due to awful stats). They tie it into his fascination with rocks extending to meteors. Then when they did the Hoenn chapter of the Villain arc, they released Sygna Suit Steven & Deoxys which actually flowed really well with what they had already written. They try to redo the Delta Emerald plot of going to stop a meteor that's going to hit the island and is causing Kyogre and Groudon to go nuts, and only Steven's Rayquaza can Mega Evolve to do it. However, a meteor piece broke off and Deoxys came from it, and it kept going after them and impeding their progress because Deoxys and Rayquaza are rivals in media. Eventually he manages to subdue and catch it while Zinnia manages to finally get her Rayquaza to Mega Evolve and take out the meteor.

They're finally upgrading Leon so his Charizard can Gigantamax, so it's likely we'll see similar upgrades for Maxie and Archie in the future. Lusamine has Pheromosa because she resembles it. Sygna Suit characters are their "serious" outfits.

>>53211935
For me it's "How does the event have a lasting effect on the characters?"

Kanto event didn't really do much except power up Giovanni, but he's relevant throughout all the events so okay.

Sinnoh event actually created stakes (Cyrus is about to mass suicide the island by putting them in an infinite nightmare), though it killed its own cliffhanger halfway through by revealing that Dawn already had a solution with Cresselia. But the way it managed to wrap up Cyrus' character arc was really satisfying, how he realizes that there is value in spirit and that perhaps it's worth trying to complete the incomplete spirit rather than outright eliminating it.

Johto is satisfying for Silver as a character overcoming his aversion to teamwork and acknowledging his own weakness. These are things he's done before, but it manages to do it in an ultimate test sort of way by having it be over Giovanni, the reason he had all his hang-ups to begin with. The Johto Sygna Suits are also the best possible choices, and Ethan and Silver teaming up using Lugia and Ho-Oh to try and overcome Giovanni while Kris, Lyra, and all the Johto Gym Leaders hold off the rest of Team Rocket is really cool, and it emphasizes that Silver needed everyone.

Hoenn has good ideas, but the writing isn't interesting and it's disjointed. We have a meteor, we have Rayquaza, we have Deoxys, that works together well enough, and Masters ties it to Steven through his interest in stones. And we have Kyogre and Groudon going nuts because of the meteor, and Courtney and Matt going nuts with them. I think the way it has Maxie and Archie putting everything aside to work together as heroes to stop the destruction is good, but the plots are too separated. It's Brendan and May trying to stop Groudon and Kyogre, yet they feel like they're there just because, they don't serve any themes. Zinnia gets her relevance, but I just can't be assed to care about her. They don't even show a flying to space cutscene.

That one was really good because it built on several pre-existing stories and tied them together in a way that was natural and had a strong theme. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53211394
You can manip it if your save file started when the internal battery died.
When the game starts, because no days have passed yet, it initializes to the PID of 0x00000000 and if the days never continue, it will remain that number. As a result you can go ahead and RNG manip a Pokemon whose PID is also that and get to Mirage Island.
If you started your game before the internal battery died, you pretty much cannot RNG manip it as you will never know what the value should be.

>>53210219
The geographic north pole (90 N) is the point where the Earth spins about its axis. The magnetic north pole is where compasses point to. For reasons that I'm too lazy to go into, these two aren't quite the same; in fact, the magnetic north pole drifts around. Lately it's been moving quite quickly. The borealis centers on the magnetic north pole, because it's a magnetic phenomenon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53210431
> This fact means that the north end of a magnet in a compass is attracted to the south magnetic pole, which lies close to the geographic north pole.

> Earth's geographic and magnetic poles are not exactly aligned because they arise from different mechanisms. Earth's magnetic field is caused by circulating currents of liquid iron in the outer core. Furthermore, earth's magnetic poles are constantly changing location relative to earth's geographic poles. Currently, the magnetic south pole lies about ten degrees distant from the geographic north pole, and sits in the Arctic Ocean north of Alaska. The north end on a compass therefore currently points roughly towards Alaska and not exactly towards geographic north.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53206404
I imagine the process after capturing a Pokemon is something along the lines of;
>capture
>win trust, travel and care for it, battle weaker mons it wants to fight on its own (several months)
>begin to coordinate, communicate more effectively, it follows basic commands now (up to another year)
>trainer battles, care to avoid constant fainting as it can lose trust in your abilities
>potential evolution in another year or several depending on the mon
By then you'd have invested minimum 3 years into a decently strong Pokemon, potentially less (Route 1 encounters) or more (Baby pseudos, fished up Pokemon). So it does make more sense to buy an Egg from a breeder for your kid, because I doubt pet mons like Meowth/Glameow would be partial to battling just because you grew up with them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208120
Gulf coast area. There was a lot of prep building up to getting into the waters, and most of it was in pools and lakes nearby at camping areas.
I definitely didn't think it was anywhere near enough preparation. It gave off a vibe of high-school cheerleading with how fucking insane it was safety-wise. Rip tides, jellyfish stings, the occasional shark. The danger is real.
We had a full staff keeping an eye at all times, and luckily nothing too bad ever happened, but it's still scary.
It did a lot of good for the kids, but it could have been so bad so often.
I still get postcards years later from them, now as adults, saying it was a turning point in their lives. Which is awesome. Just like. Damn.
Anyway, huge respect for helping guide them as a coach. It can take a lot out of you.

decided to backtrack and post story from then anyways
-
It'd been about a week since Hannah's solitary triumph at Elesa's gym. By now, the group were ready to move on from Nimbasa, and leave it and Tex behind.

They crossed the Dritfveil bridge, exchanging pleasantries and trying to make their circumstances slightly less awkward, eventually arriving where they'd initially intended to end up...
...Driftveil.

The city was... a little less spectacular than Pillow had imagined. Mostly a collection of warehouses and large one-story homes. The most notable building to its name was the church on a hill in the north, and maybe the mines even further north than that.

Regardless of its plain qualities, Pillow was... relieved. Relieved to be here. She'd accomplished something, and this city was quaint- much unlike the hustle and bustle of the last few they'd visited. The change was quite refreshing, and such a sentiment was soon echoed by Sylvia.

The group promptly split, just for a moment. Tea and Hairdo wanted to find where the gym was, while Sylvia and Pillow decided to go and hang out near the Cold Storage in the north. Hannah tagged along for the company, though she didn't talk much.

When the girls got there, however, they were given plenty to talk about.
That Beheeyem pair and their Braviary boss could be spotted once again, up on a podium and seemingly trying to rile up the Pokemon living there- spouting untruths about how Pokemon had been treated as second-class citizens, and citing the contempt the workers of the Storage had for the wilds living there. The tactic seemed to be working, as the small crowd of mon that'd gathered around the mysterious trio seemed rather loud and excited.

So excited, in fact, that a Herdier in the crowd quickly took notice of the newcomers I've been documenting and rushed to hold up Hannah specifically as an example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53204714
"Look, look!" the Herdier exclaimed, holding up a claw to the Bolt badge shining on Hannah's shoulder. "You're right, Mr Ghetsis sir! This Boldore even has a badge bolted right into her shoulder!"
An ineffectual paw at the accessory yielded little movement, prompting the dog to continue with a slightly more disgusted expression. "I bet her trainer forced her to fight until she was exhausted, and made the badge this way so that he could show off!"

This stranger was, of course, smacked away by Hannah soon after. The only reason she hadn't done so sooner was purely due to how tired she was after Nimbasa. In that respect, the Herdier had a point. Hannah could really use some time to rest after that.

The Braviary called back, though, a grin forming on his beak as the entire crowd turned to the new trio. He quickly affirmed the Herdier's train of thought, giving a sharp nod toward the Herdier and continuing to make an example of Hannah. "Truly despicable behavior. But it's to be expected from humankind, now isn't it?"

Pillow and Sylvia just watched on in exasperation as the crowd began to slowly cut them off from her. It didn't seem an intentional effort- it was too scattershot for that- but it did make things much harder for the two mon who actually KNEW Hannah, and wanted to prevent her identity from being twisted into one of victimhood. Eventually, the crowding got so bad that Sylvia attempted to Slash her way through, only to be instantly bombarded by a crowd of already-riled-up attendees.
Pillow quickly came to her aid, as did Hannah, though the crowd proved hard to beat back. Hannah especially nearly drowned in the swarm, only making her way out of it by creating an entire cage of rocks around her with her Rock Slide attack.

She introduced herself as Pansy- a well-liked member of the Cold Storage wilds who'd migrated there from Route 6- before immediately taking responsibility and offering to help the group with any expenses they might accrue as result of the mob.
Thankfully, those totalled to a three-digit number, but the Deerling found herself wanting to stick with the group regardless. So she took them on a tour of the city once the payment was well and done, too. Just for good measure.

From there, the girls reunited with the boys and told of all that'd happened. Their goal returned to beating the gym, though where to go from there... not many of them were sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After their clean victory against Clay, the future of Pillow's team was uncertain.

Everyone was looking to her for input. She was the one who'd wanted to come to Driftveil in the first place, and now she wasn't sure if she'd be leading the team out of it.

Back at Clay's, Tea had evolved. Maybe this was where his conquest for strength would end? And Pillow- she'd received a Moon stone from the miner. It hadn't been used yet, but... it was only a matter of time until that was no longer true.
Nervous, the Munna simply looked to her accomplices.

Hairdo seemed ambivalent to the whole affair, looking moreso in Tea's direction than Pillow's. Hannah just looked *tired,* more in need of a rest than anyone else. She smiled towards Pillow as they locked eyes for just a moment, though it was clearly half-hearted. Sylvia and Tea were talking amongst themselves, both very enthusiastic- Sylvia at Tea's evolution, and Tea at Sylvia's absolute annihilation of Clay's team.

Did they really need her here?
Pillow opened her mouth to suggest something, only for Tea to shout over her. "Come on, let's go to Mistralton! There's no way anything else'll be able to stop me, and I want a challenge!"
Both concrete pillars were raised in triumph as the Conkeldurr exclaimed as much, with Sylvia giggling along with her dodging of them.

Their minds were made up, then.
Pillow huffed, before floating off towards Route 6 with little more than a nod. It took some time until she heard the rest of them follow.

Eventually, the five-man band made it to... a cave? Right, they'd have to go through Chargestone.
Hairdo led the way, making sure the rest were following as he stepped right in. The static atmosphere immediately made his feelers twitch, though he ignored the discomfort in favor of figuring out where exactly they were going. Thankfully, finding that out didn't take too long...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208723
Floor after floor passed the parade by. Hannah seemed to grow weary with each passing one, increasingly slowing and sometimes wincing for no clear reason at all. All the while, they saw shadows of several different mon, all indistinguishable. The only unifying factor amongst them all was a badge branded with a familiar P.

By the time they'd made it to the deepest parts of the cavern, something was clearly wrong. Aside from Hannah now cringing like she'd suffered some kind of severe injury, Pillow could immediately make out multiple Plasma Grunts lining the halls. All human- all looked semi-lucid, unlike the rabid attackers from before. Looked...

Hannah eventually keeled over, prompting the entire hall to stare daggers in the group's direction. That look only meant one thing- *fight.*
Within seconds, grunts were assailing them on all sides. Sometimes they were accompanied by far more competent Pokémon, sometimes they simply lunged at the group as if they were Pokémon themselves. Fight after fight, battle after battle- the team began to grow weary. But eventually, the circle surrounding Hannah was engulfed in a brilliant red glow-
-and were soon met with the sight of a Gigalith, taking no time at all to join in the fight.

While the entire debacle went down, there was a moment- just a moment- that'd engulfed Pillow and shaken her once more.
Just as the light flashed, she was met with the immediate face of Snorkel, once more. Very clearly in front of her, staring right into her, wearing Plasma gear.

Her immediate reaction was rather obvious. She was going crazy, right? She was going crazy. There was no way he was standing right there.
And yet, once the scarlet glow of her compatriot's evolution dissipated, Snorkel remained. Like a Deerling in the headlights.

And then he was gone, running down the hall like they were never supposed to see him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208772
It was only after everyone had long left the cave that Pillow managed to come to her senses.

Tea Burr had ended up restraining her, tired of her attempts to chase after something the Conkeldurr was sure wasn't even there.
Only Sylvia had objected to the idea, and was quickly deterred after seeing just how frantic the Munna had gotten.

That same Munna now lay on a cushion, staring at the ceiling of the Mistralton City Pokemon Center, facing four mon with clear disappointment in their faces.
Behind them stood Skyla, gym leader.
She promptly explained what'd happened since- Pillow had freaked out, only to pass out, and be brought to the center while sometimes kicking in what she could only assume was her sleep.

Pillow sat up instantly, trying to explain the situation in the same frantic tone she usually used. Her team expressed an equally-disapproving response, with Hannah not even looking her in the eyes.
The Munna begged for her to be believed just one more time, only for Skyla to intervene and shake her head. She explained that if this Patrat really was supposed to be dead, then Pillow was likely just having hallucinations. But, she continued, there was a certain place on Route 7 that could help settle this once and for all.

Celestial Tower... that was their next destination.

>>53208815
The trek to Celestial Tower was a quiet one. Mostly filled with meaningless small talk and cutesy chatter. By now, the team was beginning to realize that there was little reason for them to have a goal- just being together was fun enough for them to go along with it. Though, plenty still found it meaningful to have something to aim for...

...suddenly, Sylvia began to notice a sixth pair of footsteps accompanying theirs. She turned left to see a quiet Audino walking a short distance away from them, seemingly tracing their trail. She paid no mind to him for a little while, but by the time the Tower was in view she began getting suspicious, so the Leavanny stopped a moment and introduced herself to the stranger.

The stranger introduced himself back, naming himself as Potpourri, and claiming to be headed towards Celestial Tower for a relative.
Pillow overheard and floated over, but didn't say anything at first. Nor did Sylvia; she just nodded and gave her apologies, before continuing towards the tower with the rest of the group.

And once they arrived, the long climb upwards began.
There wasn't much trouble, for the most part, save for the soul-sucking candles melted atop many of the graves. Occasionally someone would claim to see an alien, or a trainer near the graves would attack.
Such minor issues eventually began to pile up over time, and around halfway through the tower the team began to tire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209835
Once exhaustion began to seep into the group's mood, Potpourri finally spoke up. He offered herbal remedies to the group, and general medical care while they were there. For free.

The team didn't hesitate, and Potpourri got to helping them. He hummed a little tune as he applied tonics and pastes and bandages and berries. He made small talk, gave encouragement, and generally helped everyone press on- before once again fading into the background, with little more than a happy smile on his face.

The quintet was too busy making it to the top to question things. So much so that, when they got there, Pillow was somewhat surprised when Potpourri stepped forward and expressed his intent to ring the bell. Initially, the Munna floated forward to ring the bell herself, but... hesitated.

Potpourri took that as a resignation, and he stepped forward to ring it himself.
Once he did, another Audino came forward- about his height, but noticeably more torn. The two conversed for a time, with Potpourri acting as if the occurrence was completely normal throughout, before stepping back and motioning for Pillow to take the reins.

And so, the Munna floated forward and rang the bell...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209878
...ring, ring...

The sound echoed throughout the area, and with each ding came forth another spirit. Goggles, Snorkel, Mittens, Tex- each one came forward, all setting their sights on Pillow as the Munna realized just how many other mon she'd seen pass on.

Upon seeing Tex, however, Hannah was the first to come forward, instantly going over to the Sandile to profusely apologize and ask useless questions about his mood or how he was feeling. Tea noticed Mittens and came over to apologize for not listening to the Pansear back in Pinwheel.

Pillow just... stared.
He was really dead, wasn't he?
She didn't know what this meant. Whether she really had lost her mind, or whether the bell was faulty, or... what.
But that didn't matter. In the moment, Snorkel was right there, waiting for her to say something.
And so she did.

Nearly an hour passed before the spirits began to fade. Sylvia and Potpourri hung back while the rest of the team conversed with them- Hairdo eventually coming to join them and talk with both Mittens and Tex. It wasn't easy on any of them- Tea was bawling, Hairdo couldn't help but shed a tear, and even Hannah- though she tried to hide it- wept for Tex.

Pillow...
Pillow seemed fine, at first. Once Snorkel slipped away from her, there was no reaction. Neutrality. Ambivalence.

Before she began to break down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209942
Nobody came to her, at first. They weren't sure whether comforting someone who'd gotten them in so much trouble was a good idea, and Hairdo especially had already written her off as having lost her mind a long time ago.

Then Sylvia came over to give her a hug.
Hannah gave her a slight nudge.
Tea came over just to finalize it.

Pillow was almost in disbelief. Both of the hug and of Snorkel. She knew he was gone, and there he was- among the dead. But...
...
...no, that didn't matter.

The Munna simply accepted the hug, remaining in the group's embrace until her tears finally left her.
It was time to move on, and she'd accepted that.

The group eventually began making its way down the stairs. Pillow floated after them, with Potpourri lingering just a little longer to give the bell another look.
As the Munna descended, she figured out the perfect way to leave her more neurotic self behind for good-

-and left Celestial Tower as a Musharna.
From there on out, only two things mattered. That her team was safe, and that the next gym was defeated.
Snorkel could wait.

I am very glad that I can finally put this arc to rest because writing unlikeable characters hurts when they're also delusional and unjustified
Pillow was a shithead whom I gave too much attention, and I am more than happy to move on lmfao
hopefully she wasn't as irritating to read as she was to write lol

Most battles started like this
>Lead gigalith sand stream, AI goes for ground move/fighting move/water move/maybe a grass move
>switch to gyarados, intimidate and not very effective/immunity. AI goes for its coverage electric/rock move
>switch to excadrill
>life orb sand rush EQ/Rock Slide/Iron Head/Aerial Ace kills everything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53210835
The E4 itself was pretty cut and dry, here are the individual kill counts:
Slate - 4
Cobalt - 3
Navy - 2
Bubblegum - 1 (with an assist)
Scarlet - 8 (queen shit)
Periwinkle - 2

Now onto the main event...
Cobalt sang his Perish Song to Gyarados, the two traded blows then we switched in Periwinkle & Aerodactyl. I predicted T!Fang and sent in Slate to a Rock Slide. Now this is where the fun begins. Slate mows down Aero with 2 Rollouts and the injured Gyara with a 3rd. Out comes the first Drago who misses a Dragon Rush and dies to the 4th. Slate then tanks a Rush from the second Drago and steamrolls him with the 5th.

Things are looking amazing, the battle is now 6v2. Lance sends out his ace Drago and I switch in Periwinkle, who is crushed immediately with an Outrage. Scarlet goes in to tank the Outrages and land some Wing Attacks. I bait a Fire Blast and switch into Cobalt, but before my precious froggy can freeze this mf, Drago outspeeds and brutally murders Cobalt w/ Outrage. Scarlet flies back in to repeat the same strat from before. Her health is now yellow and Bubblegum comes in to tank a Fire Blast before Body Slamming Drago. The tyrant is finally dead!

All that's left is Charizard, who spams Air Slash while I counter w/ Milk Drinks and Body Slams when possible. At this point Lance still has all but 1 of his Full Restores, so he heals whenever BG gets Zard down to yellow. BG nerfs him w/ Captivate and paralyzes again, so Zard switches to phys attacks and burns BG w/ Fire Fang, making it harder to wittle his health down. Predicting Dragon Claw, Navy comes out and hits hard w/ Night Slash, then somehow TANKS AN AIR SLASH (thank god for Captivate). Knowing Navy, Scarlet & BG are too weak to finish off Zard, I risk it all on Slate, who eats a Fire Fang and mauls Zard w/ a final Rollout.

Never would I have thought a Donphan would slaughter Lance's almost entire team w/ Rollout. Now to lay two dear friends to rest and prepare for a new journey to Kanto.

Leave gameplay gimmicks aside for a second and consider the fundamental mechanic changes that Pokemon have made.

>Post-gen 2 EV's
>Natures
>Abilities
>Phys/Spec split
>HM/TM's
>Egg move variance
>Etc.

What are the pros and cons of these changes and would you reverse or change any of them?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53212088
>Post-gen 2 EV's
Slap a boost on for shinies so they get to go 10% over 252 in a single stat.
>>Natures
Keep em, random enough and we have ways to change them via mints.
>>Abilities
Some need to be reworked.
Example : Kee eye = 20 Accuracy boost
>>Phys/Spec split
Stats of pre gen 4 mons whose move pools are mostly physical need to be reworked, swap Sceptiles physical and special stats for example.
>>HM/TM's
HM moves need to be buffed and should be executable by any mon that can learn them even without being in the active move pool.
Buff Cut into a high crit 60 BP steel move.
Buff Flash to give a Spa boost.
Buff Rock Smash to 60 BP and make its secondary effect activate 100% of the time.
Buff Strength by making it a Rock type move with a 30% chance of boosting the users Atk and Def.
Buff Fly by making it a single turn 110 BP/90Acc 10% flinch chance attack that causes crash damage on user when missing.
Same for dive but lowering evasion and Def/SpD instead of crash damage.
Rock Climb becomes a Ground type move and is able to hit flying or levitating targets otherwise unchanged.
>>Egg move variance
Could use some expanding, maybe also differentiate some of the egg groups like Field or mineral more.
Slap on dragon or monster egg groups on some mons that should have them like the Aggron line.

Neither of my posts are incorrect. The only way to go from Blackthorn to Route 44 is through the Ice Path, there is no other direct path that doesn't result in the player warping somewhere else. There's no need for them to be connected ingame.

>>53208188
The game trying to give you a challenge without being impossibly hard is bad design now?

The way the level curve is setup means that there are two main challenges throughout the story, which are the elite 4 (level 40-50 while the player is level 30-40) and red (level 77-81 while the player is level 50-60). There are other challenges in the game like whitney, clair, blue, or silver but they're not overlevelled at all.

Both cases make total sense given what they are meant to represent, and yet are still beateable without grinding if the player has a good strategy (red can even be beaten with level 5 mons). At most, you could complain that it takes a long time to match red's pokemon levels, but that's exactly the point - he has been training there for years without talking to his mom, he better have an impressive team to show for it. If you raise the level curve to match the players level with his he doesn't look mpressive at all (like the fiasco that was diatha as a champion), and if you max out red's level to preserve the difficulty you make it impossible for less talented players to outgrind him.

While there are problems with gen 2, the level curve isn't one of them (even though it would be nice for the game to adjust the levels dynamically)

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

>>53185858
The devs decided to determine Spinda's pattern by splitting the 32-bit personality value into 4 8-bit chunks that represent each spot's y and x positions:
>first 4 bits: left face spot y coordinate
>next 4 bits: left face spot x coordinate
>next 4 bits: right face spot y coordinate
>next 4 bits: right face spot x coordinate
>next 4 bits: left ear spot y coordinate
>next 4 bits: left ear spot x coordinate
>next 4 bits: right ear spot y coordinate
>last 4 bits: right ear spot x coordinate

Those last 8 bits are also used to calculate gender, which is done by checking if that chunk is greater or equal to a specific value. On a mon with a 1:1 ratio like Spinda, this works out so that the first 4 bits of the gender chunk in male mons are always* greater or equal to 8 - since this is also the y-coordinate of the right ear spot (keep in mind that vidya coordinates almost always treat positive y as down), male Spinda always* have lower spots than females.

*Incidentally, the gender ratio actually is skewed in favor of males, but only because the programmers used a greater than equal comparison instead of a greater one - the real ratio is 129/127. As such, there's a 1/129 chance that a male Spinda can have the same right ear spot height as a female.

'Face' spots are moved down from their initial position, and 'right' spots are moved to the right. >>53192302
I am glad you and others are enjoying the tread. I am surprised and happy that it is still going.

Here is Spinda pattern 0x88888888 in Pokémon Alpha Sapphire. It turned out to be not too much more harder to make than the gen 5 Spinda I posted earlier in this thread. Starting in gen 6 the Encryption Constant starts generally taking on some of the roles of the Personality Value so I just had to put 88888888 in the Encryption Constant instead of the Personality value to make it work. When transferring Pokémon from gen 5 to gen 6 the Encryption Constant is set to the Personality Value. This pattern looks pretty nice in 3D. This should mean that most patterns should translate reasonably well into 3D but I guess that someone would need to see the pattern they wanted for themselves in the game to be sure.
